instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: I am writing this because my last post would not let me edit/remove/change headline. I have decided that my screen was just bad, and it was by chance that it burnt out as I was checking it out... works on a known good... fair enough.  My problem is the Track Pad does not work, Have plugged in a new one, doesnt work. External works fine, internal old and internal new dont.  I looked at as much of the circuit as I could, but everything seemed to check out. In fact 3.3 V is coming in at P1 and 5V on Pin 4 at J4800, anyone have any idea? I am so tired of this board.  Also, the TBT circuitry is non-op... Does this matter? All other functions except TPad work... Any Suggestions?

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: Measure pin 3 and 5 in diode mode red probe to ground and black probe to each pin, report values.....

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message:
.578 on both with pad plugged in 
1.389 on both with pad out

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: I notice it's .71 on known good (w/out). Will interrogate those circuits. But suggestions would be welcome! [USER="36"]aprendiz[/USER]

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: Check pull up resistors R5370-R5371 and SMC area, maybe some corrosion.....

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: Was just typing. No corrosion, good 1k resistance. [USER="36"]aprendiz[/USER]

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: I was hoping you wouldn't say that. [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] any suggestions?

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message:
I see no reason to test the temp. sensor data lines to the SMC here..... SMC will have no effect on trackpad operation as far as I know.
You will need to check all connections from the trackpad connector to U4801. Could be a bad connector or trace. Also verify 3 and 5V make it to the connector on the trackpad.

Just read and removed the original post. Screen is probably fine looks like the cable to me.

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message:
[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER], thanks for removing the original post. It was indeed the cable for the screen. My first hint should've been the semi-melted wifi/camera/lvds cable, plastic cover. 

I am getting voltage on those two pins, wouldn't that indicate continuity? Any idea what could cause the higher voltage drop on pins 3 & 5?
Checking around u4801, would I just look for continuity with the connector pins?

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: [USER="1"]larossmann[/USER] [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] could not having new track pad in its spot on the palm rest make a difference? I tested a known good board at the connector right next to the subject at hand, and everything was identical at the connector.

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message: All voltages are the same and behave the same. The clk pins build and release, build and release on both.

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message:
It should work outside the case at least somewhat. 

Again measure all the connections in diode mode with a cable plugged in on the trackpad side and with the trackpad disconnected.

threads.title: Keyboard YES TPad NO 820-3476
threads.message:
P1 .46
P2 .70
P3 .71
P4 .448
P5 .71
P6 0
P7 .698
P8 .698
P9 .698
P10 .697
P11 .697
P12 0

Pretty much matches known good. Could the U4801 chip be bad? [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER]
